msgSnippet: ... How about a real-world example?  :-) Such as opening a database connection and then making a query?  Or ordering methods and then calling them in that
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> The code still does something reasonable from the standpoint
> of the object. Obviously the algorithm may be changed. For
> instance, I can call drawLine before drawRect, in which case
> the rect is drawn on top of the line if they overlap, or I
> can call them in the reverse order in which case the line is
> drawn on top. But from the perspective of a Graphics object
> neither order is wrong.

How about a real-world example? :-)

Such as opening a database connection and then making a query? Or ordering
methods and then calling them in that order? Or creating widgets, adding
listeners and then starting the main Swing thread?

> The problem comes about when people design APIs that require
> something like g.initializeContext(), g.setColor, and
> g.setFont before I'm allowed to call g.drawLine. Any
> initialization that's necessary for an object to get into its
> correct state should be performed in the constructor.

It's good advice, it's just impossibly hard to achieve in reality.
Otherwise, we would never need setters.

> Complicated sequences of code execution are relics of
> procedural thinking.

We're not talking about "complicated" but "ordered".
